title: Adrienne Choquette
text:
Adrienne Choquette (1915 – 1973) was a writer in <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>, Canada.
Biography.
The daughter of Dr. Henri Choquette, She was born in <a href="Shawinigan">Shawinigan</a> and studied with the <a href="Ursulines%20of%20Quebec">Ursulines</a> at <a href="Trois-Rivi%C3%A8res">Trois-Rivières</a> from 1924 to 1931. Choquette began work with the Quebec public service but soon gravitated towards journalism. She contributed to various newspapers and journals, including "Le Bien Public", "<a href="Le%20Nouvelliste%20%28Quebec%29">Le Nouvelliste</a>", "", "La Revue populaire", "Le Jour", "Amérique française", "<a href="Le%20Devoir">Le Devoir</a>" and "Les Cahiers de l'Académie canadienne-française". From 1937 to 1948, she worked at radio station <a href="CKOB-FM">CHLN</a> in Trois-Rivières, serving as host and director for the station. From 1948 to 1970, she was co-editor and then editor for the Quebec <a href="Ministry%20of%20Agriculture%2C%20Fisheries%20and%20Food%20%28Quebec%29">Ministry of Agriculture</a> publication "Terre et Foyer".
Choquette published her first book "Confidences d'écrivains canadiens-français" in 1939. She published her first novel "La Coupe Vide" in 1948. In 1954, her story collection "La nuit ne dort pas" was awarded the . Her 1961 story collection "Laure Clouet" received the Prix du Grand Jury des lettres.
Death and legacy.
She died in <a href="Quebec%20City">Quebec City</a> at the age of 58.
In 1980, the Société des écrivains canadiens de langue française created the Prix Adrienne-Choquette in her honour. Rue Adrienne-Choquette in <a href="Saint-Augustin-de-Desmaures">Saint-Augustin-de-Desmaures</a> was also named after Choquette.
Her former home in Shawinigan has been designated as a Quebec heritage property.
